The ev'ning sun declares the day is spent:</br>The drum's tatoo and fife's responsive glee</br>Each soldier bids retire to his tent,</br>And leave the world to sentries and to me!
Now o'er the camp scarce gleams the twilight ray,</br>And all is hush'd throughout the whiten'd plain,</br>Save in the rear occurs some wanton fray,</br>Or from the mess-room sounds a jovial strain.
Save that from yonder cliff, where breaks the wave,</br>The pickets challenge strangers seen below;</br>And such as pass, nor countersign may have,</br>'Till morn, in rear, or quarterguard bestow.
Beneath the cloud-rob'd moon where lowly rise</br>Those tents, — in each, the measure of a grave,</br>Five crowded vet'rans close their low'ring eyes;</br>Such is the bed of Honour — and the Brave!
'Tis but one shot, and each no more may hear</br>The loud reveillee greet the op'ning morn;</br>No more the angry adjutant shall fear,</br>Or haste for guard his person to adorn:
No more for him shall Kate the soup prepare</br>With verdant cresses, and wild marjoram sweet;</br>No more with him, the soldier's ration share,</br>Or Sunday's walk, or pay-day's welcome treat.
Oft in the embattled field, he'd danger face;</br>As oft returning with his constant Kate:</br>How jocund then the sun-burnt pair embrace,</br>How quaff their nut-brown ale, and smile at fate!
Let not the agent of their dues beguile,</br>Or mulct the comforts of the veteran band,</br>Nor peaceful tenants of this happy Isle</br>Neglect the men, who fought, and saved their land!
The patriot's speech, — the gentle courtier's place,—</br>And all that power can give, or flattery get,</br>Await alike some paragraph to grace:</br>The grant of honours lead to the Gazette!
Despatches ne'er record the soldier's name;</br>Senates vote thanks to armies in the mass!</br>Yet may each soldier have a separate claim,</br>And noblest service may unheeded pass!
Perhaps within that canvas cell may rest</br>Some genius formed for stratagems and war;</br>Some partizan that might have taken Brest,</br>Or engineer, to plan it, from afar!
But them no military school inform'd,</br>No schemes of war did show, no tactics teach;</br>They knew not why, — they yet the fortress storm'd!</br>They knew not how, — they got within the breach!
Full many a child of nature and of love,</br>Known to no parent, thro' the world doth stray;</br>Full many a star which makes the heaven above,</br>Doth gleam unnoticed in the milky way.
Perhaps some village NELSON may be there,—</br>For star and ribbon, with a Corporal's knot;</br>Perhaps the tent some private veterans share,</br>Worthy the gallant LAKE'S high honor'd  lot!
To wield Britannia's thunders o'er the main,</br>To lead her warlike troops with vengeful arm,</br>Her laws with temper'd wisdom to sustain,</br>To rule her councils, and avert th' alarm,
Their lot forbade!  nor yet alone did bar</br>The rise of genius, but the growth of crime;</br>Forbade to make a shameful trade of war,</br>And manage contracts in a foreign clime!
The claims of rival merit to suppress,</br>The better thus to make their own appear:</br>The tale of victory with art to dress,</br>And gain by garbled truths their Sovereign's ear!
Yet — e'en the humble veteran to raise,</br>Tradition gives the story and the song;</br>Rude, yet alluring, are the notes of praise,</br>That cheer the march, and urge the line along!

Look, gentle stranger, on that parchment roll;</br>Their names thou'lt read — for thou canst read — they say;</br>Their humble virtues too — the nether scroll</br>In simple truth and language doth display:

"Ne'er did they leave their arms to rust a spoil:</br>Ne'er vilely barter shirts of shoes for gin;</br>Ne'er skulk their duty — or refuse their toil;—</br>Ne'er feign a tale to take their captain in."
Tho' far from glory's summit, and the meed</br>Of mighty actions, wide recording fame,</br>Yet, for their country, were they proud to bleed,</br>Whilst brother soldiers praised a soldier's name.
For who to coward infamy a slave,</br>Fled e'er untimely from the well-fought day?</br>E'er left his foe the laurel of the brave,</br>Nor felt one willing, warlike wish to stay?
On some fond love proud honour still relies,</br>Some praise from Nancy still the heart requires!</br>E'en when in glory's field the soldier dies,</br>E'en from the cottage glowed his martial fires.
For thee, — who ask'st the soldier's humble worth,</br>Who waits this evening's chill in solemn mood,</br>Haply his comrades say — "He trod this earth</br>With love and honor, for the wise and good.
"His mien was careless, and his manners gay,</br>Yet now he'd sudden knit the pensive eye;</br>And now with folded arms, he'd musing stray,—</br>Then smile and pass the gloom of fancy by!
"Of late we mark'd him on the trim parade</br>With hair loose-tied, nor shoes, nor gaiters clean;</br>But yester morn we saw him slowly tread</br>From yonder hut, — at noon too was he seen;—
"The evening came — nor at his tent was he,—</br>Nor on parade was seen the gentle lad;—</br>The night crept on and shadow'd o'er the lea,—</br>And Laura wept, and Damon's heart was sad!
"The morrow saw  him borne on sable bier;</br>His sword and helmet o'er the corpse were spread;</br>The grave and merry gave him each, a tear:</br>And e'en the Muse, — there, last sad honours shed."
EPITAPH.</br>Kind was the youth, — and honest too,</br>Who rests his head beneath this stone;</br>For most he felt another's woe,</br>And most the faults that were his own.
The sage's lesson, — poet's theme,—</br>Alternate filled his raptured mind;—</br>But happiest was his fancy's dream,</br>Of friend that's true, and love that's kind!
Nor seek now further to disclose</br>Or aught of frailty, or of worth;</br>The God of Battles either knows,—</br>His trumpet's sound shall call them forth!</br>
